Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in Germany 🇩🇪 on December 17, 2017
Reviews.text:
Eines vorweg, diese Art der High-Tech-Grafikkarten werden bei uns gewerblich im Bereich der Bild- und Filmsequenz-Entwicklung und -Bearbeitung mit sehr großem Erfolg eingesetzt. Seit Jahren wissen wir, dass diese Gamer-Grafikkarten für derartige Anforderungen bestens geeignet sind und die notwendige sehr hohe Auflösung, Schnelligkeit, Leistungsfähigkeit und Robustheit mitbringen. Natürlich werden sie auch für das Gaming eingesetzt und liefert dort perfekt ihre Leistung ab. Die Vielseitigkeit ist auf jeden Fall sehr eindrucksvoll.

Die Grafikarte ist sehr gut verarbeitet und alle Anschlüsse sind sehr präzise und sauber gefertigt. Sie passt perfekt. Notwendig sind ein Platzbedarf von 2,5 Slots, sowie ein ausreichender Abstand zum nächsten belegten Slot, um die Luftzufuhr sicher zu stellen. Sollte ein Netzteil am Boden des Towers angebracht sein, so ist darauf zu achten, dass sich die Ventilatoren der Grafikkarte und die des Netzteils nicht gegenseitig die Luft entziehen. Dass kann zu erheblichen Kühlproblemen führen. Abhilfe würde eine Wasserkühlung der Grafikkarte bringen. Die Grafikkarte hat aber noch eine zusätzliche Raffinesse, an der schmalen Seite hinten, besitzt sie zwei Anschlüsse für zusätzliche Lüfter. Man kann also die bestehenden Lüfter steuern, man kann aber auch zusätzliche Lüfter anschließen, so wie wir es getan haben. Das ist perfekt und innovativ gelöst!

Im Betrieb ist sie durch die drei Lüfter sehr leise. Die Lüfter laufen erst an, wenn große, hochaufgelöste Bilder bearbeitet werden oder wenn im Gaming-Bereich richtig Last durch Einstellungen im hohen Auflösungsbereich von Details stattfinden. Bisher konnten alle Anwendungen und Spiele in der maximalen Auflösung betrieben werden. Die Treiber werden auf einer CD mitgeliefert, sodass einem Start nach der Installation nichts im Wege steht. Das Betriebssystem ist bei uns das Windows 10 Enterprise. Die Anschlüsse für Monitore sind soweit ausreichend. Für diejenigen, die noch DVI Anschlüsse an den Monitoren haben, können den einen vorhandenen DVI und einen HDMI mit Kupplung auf DVI Anschluss nutzen. Bisher liefen alle Anwendungen sehr flüssig und schnell. Hänger gab es bisher keine. Full HD ist bisher die Grundeinstellung. Für bestimmte Anwendungen und Spiele wird UHD eingestellt, was überhaupt kein Problem ist.

Die Grafikkarte wird im folgenden System eingesetzt:

- Tower: Thermaltake Suppressor F51 mit Fenster Silent Midi-Tower schwarz (E-ATX)
- Netzteil: Corsair CP-9020057-EU AX Serie AX1500i ATX/EPS 80 PLUS Titanium 1500Watt, Digital, Netzteil, EU
- Motherboard: Asus Prime X299-Deluxe Gaming Mainboard Sockel LGA 2066 (ATX, Intel, Aura Sync, DDR4 4000 MHz, Dual M.2, SATA 6Gb/s)
- Prozessor: Intel I9-900X, LGA 2066 Sockel
- Arbeitsspeicher: Corsair CMK64GX4M4B3200C16 Vengeance LPX 4 x 16 GB Desktop Arbeitsspeicher Kit (DDR4, 3200 MHz) Schwarz
- Grafikkarte: Asus ROG Strix GeForce GTX1080TI-O11G Gaming Grafikkarte (Nvidia, GDDR5X, Aura Sync RGB, VR, 4K Gaming)
- CPU-Kühler: be quiet! BK019 Dark Rock Pro 3 CPU-Kühler
- M.2 Speicher SSD: Samsung 960 PRO MZ-V6P1T0BW Interne Solid State Drive (1TB)
- Betriebssystem: Windows 10 Enterprise 64 bit
- MS-Office 2016
- U.a.

Absolut top gelungen ist die Software für die Einstellung der Parameter für die Grafikkarte. Hier lassen sich auch Profile definieren, die eine Anpassung der Leistung an die einzelnen Spiele zulassen. Besonders gelungen ist die Anpassungsmöglichkeit der einzelnen Lüfter Geschwindigkeiten in Abhängigkeit zur Temperatur. Die Einstellung der Sollkurven und die Darstellung des augenblicklichen Zustandes ist perfekt. Übrigens lassen sich durch die Software des Asus-Maindboards noch mehr Einstellungen vornehmen, aber auch Informationen abrufen bzw. parallel darstellen. Die Software beider Komponenten ist aus unserer Sicht sehr professionell, nützlich und Anwender freundlich.

Eine Dokumentation und weitere Informationen sind auf der Asus-Web-Seite verfügbar.

Eine sehr leistungsfähige und schnelle Grafikkarte. Was uns besonders gefällt ist, die zusätzliche Steuerung der Lüfter.

Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in France 🇫🇷 on September 26, 2017
Reviews.text:
J'ai passé une première commande en neuf sur Amazon dans une localité différente de l'actuelle... Résultat, le lendemain la commande a été annulée pour "raison de sécurité"... J'ai donc repassé commande, cependant la même offre n'était évidemment plus disponible... Donc je suis tombé sur une offre en reconditionnée intitulée "GTX 1080ti Asus ROG strix 11Go OC"... la semaine suivante j'ai bien reçu le colis en question... L'intitulé de la boite en question portait donc bien le tag "Asus Rog Strix 1080ti 11Go OC"... Bien entendu pour ma toute première commande du genre reconditionné... J'ai directement pensé à vérifier si il s'agissait bien de la bonne version (ti). Ça n'a pas loupé !... Il s'agissait en fait de la version 1080 et non 1080ti... Du-coup j'ai du renvoyer à mes frais (c'était demandé via la méthode de retour article)... Le colis a tenté d'être livré deux fois de suite pour ensuite pourrir plus d'une semaine en bureau de poste... Entre temps j'ai contacté à la fois la poste et Amazon... La poste, toujours des bons à rien, m'ont dit d'attendre quelques jours encore et que le colis sera à nouveau livré dans les deux jours... Ce qui n'a pas été fait... Derrière Amazon qui me dit d'attendre encore 10 jours pour pouvoir être remboursé si le colis est "perdu" ou en attente de pourrissement à la poste...

Résultat des course, je devais être remboursé pour l'achat foireux en offre reconditionnée et pour le retour du colis... On ne m'a pas retourné les frais de retour de l'article... Le GPU a finalement été livré à bon port.

J'ai perdu plus de vingt jours en tout, de l'argent ainsi qu'une offre en neuf à 770 euro contre ma nouvelle commande à 110 euro de plus...

la morale... N'achetez jamais du reconditionné.

Concernant le GPU en lui-même, il est silencieux et plutôt performant... cependant quoi qu'en disent d'autres... Ça ne vaut pas +800 euro !

Reviews.text:
Anfänglich etwas zur eingesetzten Kombi: Asus P9x79 Motherboard, Intel i7 4820k CPU, 16 GB Corsair 2133 MHz RAM im Quad-Channel Betrieb, Thermaltake Big Tower, 6 Lüfter. Grafikkarte frei eingesetzt ohne dass sie von anderen Karten eingeengt wird und frei „atmen“ kann. Betriebssystem Windows 10 Pro Creators Update.

Ich habe die Grafikkarte zum Austausch einer normalen ASUS GTX 1080-8G Gaming bezogen. Ich habe mir durch den Leistungszuwachs der TI einiges an Leistungszuwachs im Betrieb mit der HTC Vive VR-Brille versprochen.

Getestet habe ich ausschließlich im vollen OC-Modus ohne zusätzliche manuelle Übertaktung. Als Programm wurde Asus GPU Tweak II genutzt, dass sich in der derzeitigen Version 1.4.5.4 mit Stand 20.04.17 als ziemlich bockig darstellt. Ich habe das Programm mit mehreren Nvidia Grafikkarten getestet und es macht überall Sperenzchen. Abspeichern von Vorgaben nicht zuverlässig, Startverhalten nicht wie eingestellt. Hier ist -mal wieder- Nachholbedarf seitens Asus fällig.

Die Graka belegt 2,5 Slots (tatsächlich 3 Slots, was will man im halben noch einsetzen?). Sie ist schwer und hängt am Ende bei horizontaler Befestigung etwas durch. Eine Zotac Amp Extreme ist allerdings erheblich schwerer. Dennoch habe ich sie aus Sicherheitsgründen weiter befestigt, um den Hängen entgegenzuwirken.

Im Betrieb ist die Graka sehr leise und auch unter Vollast empfinde ich die Geräuschentwicklung nicht als störend.

Daher jetzt ohne lange Vorrede: Die Leistung ist brachial. Project Cars mit 4k@60 Hz mit allen Einstellungen auf Anschlag in ULTRA läuft absolut flüssig ohne einen einzigen Ruckler. Selbst bei den Replays ruckelt oder zuckt nichts. Dirt Rally ebenfalls alles auf Anschlag, 8* MSAA, Vsync aus bei 3840 * 2160 Auflösung ergibt bei meinem System im Benchmark die Werte:

Min. 63 Frames/Sek und max. 91 Frames/Sek. Die Grafikkarte erreicht dabei keine Temperatur über 70 Grad.

Beim Betrieb mit der HTC Vive kann sie ebenfalls punkten. Mit erweitertem Supersampling in Steam VR kann ich eine deutliche Verbesserung der Darstellung feststellen. Project Cars kommt jetzt auf ein Supersampling von 2,2 bei flüssigem Gameplay (vorher mit erheblicher manueller Übertaktung der GTX 1080 nur 1,5). Raceroom Experience kann ich auf volle 3.0 (mehr ist bei Raceroom nicht einstellbar) ohne Ruckler fahren. Assetto Corsa läuft mit einem Supersampling von 2,5 noch vollkommen flüssig.

In allen Fällen ist die Grafik in der Vive damit um einiges besser.

Es bleibt daher festzustellen. Die Aufrüstung von einer ASUS GTX 1080-8G-Gaming auf die ASUS GTX 1080 O11G TI hat sich für mich auf alle Fälle gelohnt, wenngleich der Preis ziemlich hoch ist.

Update 15.05.2017: Mit dem Tool Asus GPU Tweak II gebe ich auf. Unter Windows 10 Creators Update ist es nicht einsetzbar. Es wurde mit DREI unterschiedlichen PCs eingesetzt und führt u.a. zur spürbaren Verlangsamung ALLER Rechnersysteme!! Auch mit einer Asus GTX 1080 8G-Gaming, GTX 1070.

Lösung, um die Graka in den von Asus zulässigen Werks-OC-Modus zu bekommen: GPU Tweak II einmal installieren und die Taktwerte alle notieren. Deinstallieren und MSI-Afterburner installieren. Die vorher ermittelten GPU Tweak Profilwerte (Silent, Gaming, OC) in Afterburner-Profilen hinterlegen.

Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in France 🇫🇷 on January 11, 2018
Reviews.text:
-- MISE A JOUR du 19 Janvier 2018 --
Après votre achat, vérifiez avec un outil comme GPU-Z que les puces mémoires qu'utilise votre carte proviennent bien de SAMSUNG et non MICRON. Si ce sont des MICRON, demandez un remplacement pour produit défectueux. Référez-vous aux articles disponibles lorsque vous tapez "nvidia micron memory" en recherche sur Google pour de plus amples informations. ASUS ne distribue pas à ce jour de BIOS censé corrigé les problèmes rencontrés avec ce type de mémoire
-- FIN de mise à jour --

Déjà que cette carte graphique est le top du top de la série 10 chez NVIDIA, couplez-là à un PCB et un radiateur "made in ASUS" et vous avez là la carte ultime.

Le radiateur est largement capable de dissiper la chaleur produite par l'incroyable processeur graphique de cette carte. Le RGB, objet phare de la série STRIX chez ASUS, apporte une possibilité de personnalisation exclusive dont on ne peut plus se passer.

En ce qui concerne les performances, il n'est pas utile de s'étendre sur le sujet. L'énorme quantité de coeurs graphiques, couplés à 11 Go de RAM GDDR5X (de la GDDR5 boostée par NVIDIA) le tout refroidit par le radiateur ASUS vous permettront de profiter d'autant de 4K que vous le voulez.

Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in Italy 🇮🇹 on July 6, 2018
Reviews.text:
Scrivo "commerciale" perchè magari non tutti, ma tanti si possono permettere di spendere dagli 800 a 1000 € o quasi per questa scheda video e magari nessuno o pochissimi per spendere 3000 € per una Titan V, unica scheda superiore fino adesso a questa Strix GTX 1080 Ti oc.
A patto che si abbia anche un ottimo processore a supportarla (io ho un i7 7700k e 16 gb a 3466mhz) e un buon quantitativo di ram veloce, con questa scheda si può giocare al 70% dei giochi anche recenti in 4K a 60 fps, e al 100% almeno da me provati in 2K 60 fps e arrivare anche a 120 fps con alcuni giochi un pò più datati, e parlo cmq a dettali massimi magari non esagerando con i filtri ssaa. Non ho trovato difetti a questa scheda, è silenziosa e anche bella da vedere se si ha il resto dei conponenti che si illuminano in RGB, ma va bene anche da sola.
Occupa 2,5 slot come dimensione ed è forse appena più lunga di una strix 1080 liscia, cmq si adatta bene dentro qualsiasi case da gaming, e necessita di un buon alimentatore e due molex da 8 pin l'uno.
L'unico neo non dovuto alla scheda video, sono i prezzi che si sono alzati parecchio da un po di tempo, per il resto se si vuole il massimo da una scheda singola questa è quella che fa per voi!

Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in Germany 🇩🇪 on November 22, 2017
Reviews.text:
Ich habe mir nach langer PC Gaming Abstinenz wieder einen Gaming PC gegönnt. Hab mich ein wenig eingelesen und gerade was die Grafikkarte angeht war schnell klar es soll eine NVIDIA werden da AMD nicht wirklich an die Leistung herankommt. Ich wollte auch definitiv das Flaggschiff haben und so war klar ein muss eine GTX1080TI werden. Weitere Recherchen brachten mich auf die Strix Modelle von ASUS und hier auch auf die OC Modelle. Die scheinen solide und für TOP Performance ausgelegt zu sein.

Ich habe die Karte nun gut 4 Monate in Betrieb un kann nur sagen JA ein absolutes TOP teil. Ich spiele Destiny 2 und PUBG in 4K und schaffe damit solide Frameraten über 60FPS... JA nach Einstellungen auch mal bis 80FPS...

Die Karte ist TOP verarbeitet und sieht durch die Aura Lichteffekte auch super aus ein einem Gehäuse mit durchsichtiger Wand. Ich würde aber für den Preis auch nichts anderes erwarten.

Mit gefällt das OC Tools gut das beiliegt damit lässt sich die Karte schnell und einfach in den OC, GAME oder SILENT mode schalten. MAn merkt schon einen unterschied. Ich spiele mit Headset deswegen ist mir Geräuschentwicklung persönlich nicht so wichtig aber auch unter Volllast ist das aus meiner Sicht erträglich. Im Silent Mode stört die Karte eigentlich gar nicht.

Was ich persönlich sehr cool finde sind die vielen Anschlüsse. Die Karte kommt mit 2 x HDMI, 2 x Displayport und einem DVI Port. Hier sollte jeder ohne große Mühe seine Monitore angeschlossen bekommen. Wenn man ein VR Headset hat ist der HDMI Port Praktisch. Sind beides HDMI 2.0 Ports.

Wer die Karte im Budget hat dem kann ich die nur wärmstens empfehlen... Aus meiner Sicht ein wirklich gutes Preis/Leistungsverhältnis in der Grafikkarten Oberklasse.

Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in Italy 🇮🇹 on June 5, 2017
Reviews.text: Ottima scheda video!!! Da una gtx 960 4gb sono passato a questa, quindi da una fiat ad una ferrari, molto bella, robbusta e sistema di raffreddamento ottimo, molto silenziosa anche se x me lasciata così dura poco (oltre i 70 gradi) io con msi afterburner ho configurato le ventole mantenendola a 60 gradi max in gaming e fa un casino assurdo, ma mi va bene così almeno spero dura di più... La mia configurazione :Maximus hero ix, 32gb corsair 3200mhz, i7 7700k, ssd 500 samsung evo, e hhd 2tb wd, penso di stare quasi al top, eppure giochi come rise of tomb raider non va in 4k con tutti parametri al massimo, gosth recon idem... Fallout 4 al massimo oltre i 60fps, skyrim lo divora.... Diciamo fa il suo dovere.... Ragazzi parliamo di 800/900 euro solo per una scheda video, per giocare al massimo in 4k bisogna prenderne un altra e metterla in sli (1700/1800 euro solo di schede grafiche) alimentatore almeno 1100watt in tal caso altre 200 euro.... Cioè è bellissima per carità sono estremamente soddisfatto! Ci mancherebbe a 8 piotte!!! Che se nn mi soddisfava già la avevo mandata indietro, pensavo solo che in 4k avrei giocato al massimo... Tuttavia la consiglio, ovviamente ai malati come me... X chi non può spendere così o non vuole può prendere una 1070 anche una 1060, sicuro a 1080p ci giochere molto bene... Aggiornerò in futuro, sperando di aumentare le stelle.

Reviews.title: Pricey, but worth every penny...
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States 🇺🇸 on July 20, 2020
Reviews.text:
1. It's made by Nvidia themselves. Your silicon quality is guaranteed to be slightly/much better than silicon found in the same card by MSI or EVGA etc.
2. It's performance is comparable to the RTX 2080, and can provide a stunning, high fps image at 1080p and 1440p. 4K achieves stunning imagery, but averages a framerate around 68 in the games I benchmarked.
3. It's aesthetics and lighting make it fit very well in your case, especially if you have green-based RGB in mind.
4. The fans are silent up to around 80% speed and are very good at cooling down the GPU die.
5. The I/O contains 3 Display ports, 1 HDMI port and a USB C port. Good selection considering what most people buying this card will have display it's output.

To sum it all up, you're guaranteed to find a higher maximum overclock due to the better silicon, perfect 1080p and 1440p gameplay with little struggle at 4K, great aesthetics, quiet fans, and a good variety in I/O ports. Perfect for builds between $1500-$2300.

Reviews.title: Beast of a card for the price
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States 🇺🇸 on May 22, 2021
Reviews.text: I got this card for $570 before tax in September of 2020 and it does most current gen games at 1440p Ultra @ 60fps and some at 4k Ultra @ 60fps. The RTX looks nice but the card struggles above 1080p without DLSS. It also handles VR pretty well. I've had it for 9 months now and have had zero issues. It's pretty quiet most of the time but does make noticeable fan noise when it's under heavy load but I've had much louder cards in the past. I hope it holds up because by the looks of it I'm not going to be able to buy a new GPU any time soon.

Reviews.title: I've had very good results from ASUS
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States 🇺🇸 on April 23, 2015
Reviews.text:
Generally speaking, I'm not much of an overclocker. Sure, I'll tweak my settings a bit and get a few extra MHz here and there, but I'm not anywhere near the enthusiast this card is aimed at. That being said, I needed an upgrade to my aging, yet still formidable, GTX 680 and wanted something to 'future-proof' my system. I've had very good results from ASUS, with three quarters of my rig from that company, and haven't any reason to complain yet. I consider them to make quality and premium components, and this card has only reinforced that ideology. I purchased it wanting the highest quality, the most options and with an emphasis on gaming, while also bearing in mind cost per performance. To me, something like the Titan series hasn't breached that ratio yet, so after much research and probing on my end, I finally fell with the GTX 980.

To begin, just so a potential customer knows a little about me so as to weigh my opinion against others, I have been building computers for about ten years now. I am A+ and Network+ certified, and have worked the area of computers officially for the better part of three years. What started as a hobby is now my job. I surely don't know everything nor should I be considered an expert on the topic, I just happen to know a couple things and my way around a computer. I'm sure many others can say the same. Take that with as many grains of salt as you wish. On to the review.

PHYSICAL DESIGN
Aesthetically speaking, this card takes the cake. The color scheme and design is of course user preference, but I for one find it absolutely fantastic. I have the Maximus Formula VII motherboard, also with the ROG scheme, so this matches my current setup perfectly. The backplate, while not providing any real thermal benefit, does give the card a bit rigidness and stability which the card does require because of its size. The fans are of decent size and are quite noiseless, even under load (so far to date). The load bearing LED is helpful though its accuracy is debatable; I suspect software patches will increase its effectiveness over time, so I can't fault the card just yet as it is relatively new. But it's still a nice touch. The power LEDs are very helpful and let you know if the card is receiving power; upon insertion into the slot, they will glow red indicating that the card is seated but power has not yet been applied. Once proper power is given, the LEDs turn solid white. I'm sure this will be helpful when diagnosing future problems when trying to rule out power-related issues.

PERFORMANCE
As stated earlier, I'm not a heavy overclocker as of yet. I have however been able to achieve stable clock speeds exceeding 1400MHz on the GPU, and 7060MHz on the memory side of things. Not jaw dropping mind you, but very reasonable considering I am only on air-cooling at the moment. Temperatures have also been quite good, with the card barely topping out in the high sixties (Celsius) during heavy gaming. At idle it sits very comfortably at twenty seven degrees. The reference cooler, if my memory serves correctly, allows for around eighty degrees under load - quite a big difference considering I haven't modified my cooling components. I think this speaks to ASUS and their design implantation. But that is one man's opinion.

SOFTWARE
I consider the software straight forward and simple, something others may or may not appreciate. With the click of the mouse one can modify clock speeds of just about anything as well as fan speeds. By default access is given for the boost clock, memory clock and fan speed but there are a host of other options available. And most tweaking can be done without touching the voltage. But if one wishes the voltage can be unlocked and cranked up, so seasoned overclockers aren't hindered by the over-simplified approach of GPU Tweak. The monitoring extension of GPU Tweak is very good, as it tracks anything and everything about your card. If you haven't been blessed with a second monitor where you can watch temps in real time as you game, the program tracks maximum and minimum values, so upon exiting a game for example, you can see what temp your card topped out at. Same goes for clock speeds and fan RPMs.

OVERALL IMPRESSION
I love this card. This card has taken everything I've thrown at it without breaking a sweat. Longevity will of course be the ultimate decider, but for now I'm very satisfied. Expensive? Yes, there's no denying that. And there's nothing wrong with other cards from EVGA or GIGABYTE or whatever. I just happen to like ASUS and don't mind paying a little more. Choice is yours. I'd recommend if you are a gamer and plan on doing some hardcore-like things in the future (liquid cooling/nitrogen), but there is nothing wrong with keeping it on air, at least in my eyes. I'd also recommend obtaining drivers from Nvidia and utilizing their GeForce Experience program - might be all just marketing, but the program will help keep your drivers up to date. Video-game specific drivers have also been released, most notably Advanced Warfare and GTA V, so that is helpful in keeping on track. My rig is posted below as are some of the games that I play, so as to help you gauge if my findings are even relevant to your situation. Average frames per second are also given.

Core i7 4790k 4.0GHZ (OC'd to 4.6GHz)
16GB 1600MHz RAM
Intel 730 SSD
Matrix GTX 980
Enermax Coenus Mid-Tower Case
ASUS 27" 120Hz Monitor

Dead Space 3: 80 - 110 FPS
GTA V: 50 - 60 FPS
Rome II Total War: 65 - 90 FPS
Battlefield 4: 55 - 75 FPS
Mirrors Edge: 60 - 75 FPS
Half-Life 2: 120 FPS

Reviews.title: One of the best air cooled cards
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States 🇺🇸 on November 30, 2014
Reviews.text:
Using MSI Afterburner, I did some quick overclocking. The voltage slider doesn't really affect voltage. I am not sure what's going on there. nevertheless, here are the results. (So there are results without applying any additional voltage from MSI Afterburner.)

Core clock: +200MHz
Memory clock: +400MHz
Final frequency during gaming and benchmark
core: 1516MHz
memory: 7806MHz

That's both of the cards stable in SLI. These OC results are actually higher than online reviews with voltage applied for this specific card. Maybe I finally get lucky, but two cards in a row? Gotta give ASUS some credit.

3DMark Fire Strike
Ultra: 6680
Extreme: 11676

My scores are bottlenecked by my 4.3GHz 4770K. However, the Ultra score is still ranked 38th world-wide on 3dmark Hall of Fame's 2x card leaderboard. So you know these cards are one of the best. Adding in one more, you will be in top 100 world wide no doubt.

Some stats collected during stress test, with auto fan profile.
Room temperature: 24-25C

GPU1 (on top, one DVI connected):
ASIC quality: 78.7%
VDDC on OC: 1.175V
Peak temp: 77C (75-76C stable)
Peak fanspeed: 63%, 2150RPM

GPU2 (on bottom, one DVI and one HDMI connected):
ASIC quality: 72.9%
VDDC on OC: 1.212V
Peak temp: 71C (70-71C stable)
Peak fanspeed: 53%, 1500RPM

If you ask why the better card is hotter, it's because it's sitting on top. The nvidia/pcgamer folks are not lying. The thermal is a huge factor. So make sure you put your best card on top to counter the additional heat from the bottom card. Also connect as many displays to bottom card and assign PhysX to bottom card. Unfortunately I don't have DP displays or adapters to move all displays to bottom card.
http://www.pcgamer.com/sli-overclocking-guide-nvidias-tom-petersen-on-maximizing-multi-gpu-performance/

The HW fan profile apparently takes temperature and card itself into account when scaling the fan speed. So at same fan speed percentage, the fan speed is different between the cards. It also reacts to temperate a bit differently. The cooling solution is absolutely fantastic. This is actually the first time I am confident enough that HW fan profile won't cripple my OC results.

Both of them are not noisy under load. The fan only gets audible at 1500RPM, and obvious at 2000RPM. However, here obvious I don't mean noisy. The nosiest level I've ever experienced on these two cards is still quieter than official GTX780's fan during same load.

Also as advertised, the fan indeed completely stops in 2D workloads, even with 5760x1080 resolution. The temperate stays at 60C (after idling for 3min after benchmark).

Pros:
1) One of the best air cooled cards. I am totally sold on DirectCU II solution now
2) Very quiet, and stays cool even overclocked
3) Backplate is welcome
Cons:
1) Longer and wider than other GTX980s. Make sure you are not too constrained by space.
2) PCI-E mounting bracket is a bit too wide (by 0.5mm), which forces me to remove adjacent mounting brackets to make room for it on my CM Stryker case.

Pro or Con depends on personal preference:
1) White LEDs on power connectors can't be turned off. As long as MB has power, it will light up. Thus if you hate any light at night, that's a con. It's not too bright though, but very convenient to assure yourself the power connectors are intact.
2) No other lights on card.
3) Fan stops at idle, with GPUs at 60C. This is definitely safe, but indeed contributes to ambient temperature inside case. If you are the ones that would rather spin the fan a little to make it cooler, you can design your own curve in MSI Afterburner.

That's my results for now, I will run with +150/+300MHz OC for daily usage and gaming. If it breaks I will of course update, but I haven't had any GPUs failing for all the years though. That's probably because I never cheap out on power, mb or even power stripes...

I also want to thank Amazon: I discontinued my Prime membership last year, but after this order got stuck in prepare for shipping for 5 days, I started a support ticket. They changed it to 1-day shipping for free and also price matched newegg ($569.99). Then they gave me a further discount in form of refund because "Pick Your Path" promotion is not included here, but included on newegg for same SKU. These all happens within 2 days by several emails.

Reviews.title: Blown away
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States 🇺🇸 on October 17, 2014
Reviews.text:
Coming from a pretty old pair of 6970's, I was really looking forward to these cards. I was seeing benchmarks and reviews and already saw how even just one of these cards was 1.5x faster than both of mine, so to add a second one was icing on the cake. But the frames, while a big part of why I am so happy, were not the only part, not by a long shot.

1. Geforce experience and the control panel were so easy to install and keep updated. I have owned AMD/ATI for about 7 years and it was never as easy as that was. I can now look at the drivers, optimize games with a button, shadowplay and the best part for me is updating the drivers. Crazy. Everything was in tow. The drivers responded well to every game and I didn't have to fiddle with them like I did previously to get them to work correctly in games.

2. I almost forgot I was playing with MY computer in the middle of crisis 3 game. It was so quiet. Like I really couldn't believe it. When the cards aren't doing anything they are off which is great but even in game the fans are so quiet compared to the reference 6970 cards that I always prepared for and could here even when It was stuffed away behind my desk. The case was open and right next to me and I bet I heard more noise from the CPU fan than I did the cards. Best part was the cards never went above 73c. Not even the sandwiched one.

3. Everything plays on max. There is nothing these cards can't do. I play at 1080 with 120hz monitor and it just destroys like nothing before.

4. The power consumption is so little compared to how powerful they are. They already come pre overclocked but you can go even more and not have to worry. This was a reason I didn't upgrade sooner to a 290x or 780ti cause my 850w could take them but with a smaller overclock than these could.

It's not that its without a few issues though. So let me break it down.

Pro:
- Crazy fast
- Super quiet
- Super cool
- Low wattage
- Sexy design
- Pre overclocked with room for more
- Easy install and set up
- Multiple ports for all kinds of set-UPS
- Nice backplate to keep it cool and so you can hold it without worrying of breaking something

Con:
- Very big, be careful. It was much taller and longer but not thicker than my old cards. I couldn't get it fit with my HAF X case with the side fan tunnel. Once I took off the little tunnel thing, it was okay.
- Blows hot air around case. The reference cards take the air and shoot it out the ass end but these cards although very cool, kind of make the case hotter.
- SLI does not working for every game. As in the profiles have not been made. The game still runs great on one card just kind of a waste. But you can trick some games into using both cards by setting up a profile.
- One that came looked like the cooler wasn't on as good as the other. It had more give. It works fine and is cool but just slightly worrying.

I am 100% happy with my purchase. It was the best upgrade I could have done and I wouldn't have picked another supplier. Amazing cards

Reviews.title: a bit of a premium over a 970, but a great single card.
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States 🇺🇸 on December 9, 2014
Reviews.text:
I had SLI 670 DCUIIs and recently picked up a RoG swift. Gsync and 144hz cured every monitor issue I had, but made micro stutter very apparent. Before there were random stutters and I could never place a finger on what caused that particular one. After the RoG I got went down to one card and it was flawless though I had to lower the resolution. I went back to 2 and the stutters returned. I was on the fence between a 970, 980 or waiting for a 980ti but finally caved on the Cyber monday discount. I wasn't expecting a huge framerate increase over the 670s, but with a mild overclock I got about 15-20% across the board and having a single GPU is prefect for me. Also with double the texture memory many games have opened up a new level of pretties I can turn on. I went from a GTX 480 to SLI 670s and really missed the overall stability of a single monster GPU, the 980 works great.

Not that it bares much to the overall gaming experience but 3dmark firestrike went from 12021 with mildly OC'd 670s and a 2600K@4.8ghz to 14231 with a fairly heavily OC'd 980.

The only oddity that freaks me out is that the Strix 980 shuts off both fans at idle occasionally barely spinning up one fan while watching youtube vids and such but only 200-300 rpm, it tends to idle between 55-60°C but the instant you game both fans come up. Playing BF4@2560x1440 set to ultimate I get right about 60fps and the card hovers about 63-65°C with the fans around 40%, if I lower it to high I get about 135-145fps and the card hovers around 52°C with the fans at 30% which is funny that it runs cooler under load than at idle.

Overall the Strix 980 is a great quiet card. If you want more bang for the buck a pair of 970s would be better, though with the recent price decrease an R9 295X destroys anything in price to performance and is about the same price as a pair of 970s. Since I didn't want to deal with multi GPU, the 980 is perfect for me.

Reviews.title: Whisper Quiet, Power Savings, Incredible Benchmark
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States 🇺🇸 on October 16, 2014
Reviews.text:
The GeForce GTX 980 is NVIDIA's latest high-end single-GPU graphics card, made possible by the company's new Maxwell architecture. The GM204 graphics processor, which powers the GTX 980 in this review, comes with amazing power consumption improvements that are the foundation behind the GeForce GTX 970 and GTX 980 taking the enthusiast market by storm.

The GeForce GTX 980 is carved out of the 28 nm GM204 silicon with all its shaders enabled, resulting in a shader count of 2,048. There are 128 available texture units and the ROP count is a massive 64, with a 256-bit bus connecting 4 GB of GDDDR5 memory.

ASUS decided to use their recently introduced STRIX brand for their GTX 980 flagship. The card is built on a customized PCB design with an improved cooler that completely stops the fans in idle and features higher clock frequencies out of the box.

ASUS has outdone themselves yet again. The GeForce GTX 980 STRIX OC is pretty much perfect, bringing significant improvements over the already excellent NVIDIA reference design. ASUS overclocked their card out of the box, which, depending on the resolution, yields a 5-7 % performance improvement. This lets it beat any single-GPU card on the market conclusively while also making it faster than the dual-GPU GTX 690 and roughly equal to the dual-GPU HD 7990. Just like the stock GTX 980, I'd recommend the ASUS GTX 980 STRIX for full detail gaming at 1440p and 1600p, with 4K being quite playable when two cards are teamed in SLI. The difference to AMD's single GPU flagship, the R9 290X, is roughly 26%

the overclocking ability is incredible.
1499 Mhz 30% faster than the reference.
whisper quiet, when not under any considerable load.Asus really takes advantage of the Maxwell architecture and brings it to the next level. I highly recommend this purchase, running two of them in an SLI configuration is a complete beast of the setup. Full review to follow.

Pros:
+ High factory overclocked GTX 980
+ Impressive out-of-the-box performance
+ Excellent overclocking potential
+ Solid build quality with 10-phase Digi+ VRM Super Alloy Power design
+ Aesthetically stunning design
+ DirectCU II cooler with 0dB Fan Technology provides good temperature and super silent
+ Low power consumption

Reviews.title: Best card ever
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States 🇺🇸 on November 8, 2014
Reviews.text:
In the past, I've generally stuck to the $300 price range cards, but this thing was calling out to me and I had to try it.

This is simply the best card I've ever purchased. It's quiet even when the fans spin, and it's pushing smooth game play on everything I've thrown at it, on a 2k res monitor (ASUS PB278Q) and ultra graphics settings. I can get it to touch 70ºC, but no higher yet. Even at that point, the fans are spinning at 43% of max. Taking a peek at my HW monitor, it's sitting at a comfortable 32ºC with the fans off. Some people will report that their max and idle temps will be higher or lower, the variables being the ambient room temp and your case air flow or overall cooling solution. I like my case quite, so I sacrifice a bit of airflow.

It's kind of nice to have a card that can support more than 2 simultaneous monitors. I used to have to turn one off to throw a video over to my TV, but that's not necessary anymore :) It supports up to 4.

I've been an EVGA fan boy for over a decade, but in light of their recent design mishaps and customer complaints with the 900 series cards, I decided to try ASUS as I've yet to buy a bad product from them. Regrets? None.

The only CONS that are worth mentioning are:
1) This card is friggin huge: length and width. I was worried that it wouldn't fit my case with a side fan, but it does - just barely. The heat pipe looping away from the card toward the side of the case just about touches the side fan casing, but it doesn't get hot, so whatever.
2) The overclocking software from ASUS is a little buggy. The monitor panel tends to lock up and requires a restart just about all the time, but I only really needed it to set the thing up.

Reviews.title: The Best of the Best
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States 🇺🇸 on October 16, 2014
Reviews.text:
PROS:
-Quality: This card is heavy with an amazingly designed board and metal fan covers. The cooler keeps it under 64c even when benchmarking!
-Frames: I am getting 299FPS in Street Fighter 4 Ultra, 100FPS in Tomb Raider, 200s in Diablo ROS and SC2. I would highly recommend this card for people using 120 or 144mhz monitors.
-Noise: I use MSI Afterburner software to manually keep the fan on its lowest speed @ 35% then bump up while gaming. These fans are the quietest fans I've ever owned and are very efficient at cooling. I barely notice they are even on while gaming. I have a silent build in a micro ATX case.
-Aesthetics: This is a custom PCB GTX980 with a gorgeous cooler.
-Drivers: I am using 344.16 and haven't found any glitches yet. I never knew how unreliable my AMD card drivers were until now. I'll never go back at this point! AMD Fanboy converted.
-Power: This cards uses an 8pin and 6pin PCIex connection on my 550watt power supply. nvidia recommends a 500w minimum on their site. I was worried about this but haven't run into any issues yet. I'm sure my electric bill will thank me for this upgrade later on.
-Back Plate: This card isn't going to sag any time soon. I still supported it with a trash tie but it isn't needed.

CONS:
-Connections: There is only 1 DVI-D and 1 HDMI port on the back! Dispalyports are not even mainstream yet so you'll need top buy cables if you plan on using 3 monitors like myself. I knew this before I bought it but be warned.

Thoughts: I upgraded from an AMD 6870 which I held on to for a long time. I went from 23 frames to 200 frames in passmark8.0! This was the video card I was waiting for since I wanted something that ran cool, performed well and didn't take a 800w+ PSU to run like the 780ti. This is the quietest GTX980 out there and definitely the best looking. Some benchmarks show the gigabyte windforce card pumping out higher scores but it is factory clocked higher. This card runs way cooler and has a much higher overclocking headroom.

Reviews.title: Aparently defective on trying to drive more than one monitor...
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States 🇺🇸 on May 13, 2015
Reviews.text:
UPDATE 05-18-15: Amazon was super quick to send me a replacement for this card but... same as the first one. I even attempted support from Nvidia and various forums. No one seems to have ideas other than that quite possibly the first card and the replacement were both from the same batch that could be defective. My guess is that although this may be a powerful beast of a graphics card... it apparently can't handle more than 2 monitors without loss of certain Windows capabilities and driver lag. I just decided to return the replacement for a refund and will look into seeing if SLI will work with lesser beef (and price) per card. $550+ for just one of these cards and it can't handle this simple need... ugh! Sad too because I'm not exactly that much of a gamer or major photo/video editor. I'm just a major multitasker with common programs like Excel, Quicken, WMP, and IE. Therefore I hate having to explore more complex PC needs just to drive 3 monitors that are above 1080p. I hope this review has been of some help to any who my situation pertains to.

The card I got in is apparently defective after contacting ASUS. I have 2x 27" 2560x1440 monitors AND 1x 34" Curved 3440x1440 monitor in a 3-monitor setup that ASUS said the card should drive them all without graphics issues. I do get a display on all three monitors at full resolutions but Areo gets disabled and when moving folders or other windowed programs around on my screen they all trail bad and then the redraws take a few moments. Sometimes the system has issues powering down when shutting down the PC. Even scrolling is affected in some programs. Graphics drivers are up to date and even updated the VGABIOS per ASUS request... still no help. Even tried dropping the resolutions down... no help. I've tried un-plugging one of the monitors and still no help. My rig is comprised of:

ASUS Crosshair V Formula-Z motherboard
AMD FX-6350 Six-core 3.9GHz CPU
GEIL 16GB (4x 4GB) DDR3-1600 RAM
Corsair 750 TX PSU
Samsung 840PRO SSD
ASUS SATA DVD+/-RW
ASUS PCI-X WiFi card

ASUS said my rig specs are fine for this card and that my three monitor setup shouldn't be a problem so therefore the card must be defective. Amazon has issued a replacement for me and once I've swapped out the cards I will update my review....

Reviews.title: ASUS Supporft practically non-existant ... unless its about one of their headline produces of course.. other than that... nada.
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States 🇺🇸 on November 3, 2016
Reviews.text:
I make a habit of not writing bad reviews. But being an Senior IT Service Delivery Manager for years I can't stand by and let people buy something based on misleading information and poor if non-existent support. I purchased an X99 Deluxe MB, STRIX GTX 960 Graphics, ASUS Monitor, Router, and many other ASUS components because in the past I trusted ASUS quality and support and I wanted one seamless, integrated solution supported by a known quality manufacturer.

So I'm giving this 1 star because ASUS support is practically non-existent yet they will respond here with questions about (*please tell us the problem, we will support you, please e-mail us, we will open a case for your and solve your problem). Been there, done that, multiple times, over and over as you will see if you look at the thousands of people pleading for help on a product that simply does not work.

Why am I writing this really poor review? Take a look at the ASUS "Forums" and search on "HomeCloud". you will find hundreds of posts for help on that "bundled and promised to work" product, over 10,000 (you read that right "Ten Thousand") views and NOT ONE of the posts have a solution to why the "ASUS HomeCloud" produce fails over and over and over and over again. All these people are frustrated and upset that the bundled software for ASUS products simply don't work and ASUS is blowing them off for support. In fact, take a quick search on Google for ASUS HomeCloud. You'll be shocked and run as fast as you can to a different brand; i kinda wish I had but the saving grace is their hardware realy is pretty solid and perfoms very well.

So when I (and many many others) try to get support on the software ASUS promises out of the box (Home Cloud happens to be one of the explicit benefits of why I chose to go all out ASUS) I get nothing but a runaround (send us logs, send us email, re-install, reboot, etc. etc.).

If you want ASUS because you think you will get your own personal cloud storage.... don't, Go buy a different manufacturers product that will stand behind their product.

So FIX IT ASUS, then, after you've fixed it, tested it, proven it works (and by the way, that it works in the USA) go help the people pleading for help and frustrated on your and other IT forum sites about it.

Reviews.title: If you're ready for the best gaming card you've ever owned just click ADD TO ...
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States 🇺🇸 on October 10, 2015
Reviews.text:
Okay, so I wasn't sure if this would be a lateral upgrade seeing as I already had a 3 year old GTX Titan 6g.
Now I'm mad at myself for not buying the ASUS GTX 980 STRIX sooner!

I run a single 30" monitor @ 2560x1600 (1440p). This takes a lot of oomph - far more than regular old 1080p HD. All I can say is WOW!

On Attila:Total War I have everything maxed except AA (not needed at this resolution), grass (one tick down from the top), and SSAO. It runs hovering at 55-60 fps and that's with ultra sized units on as well.

In GTA V, I run everything maxed. What a pleasure to drive at 100 mph through the city with zero lag and minimal dips in fps.
Did I mention this thing is silent and never, EVER gets above 68c degrees even running Furmark at 1440p all maxed with AA on for HOURS??

If you're ready for the best gaming card you've ever owned just click ADD TO CART now.

Reviews.title: Don't buy unless Nvidia announces they've fixed the drivers issues
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States 🇺🇸 on September 29, 2021

It had a broken piece that holds the device cover on and it had marks on the cover but I figured none of that is visible (and it had other pieces to hold the cover on) and that was probably why it was so inexpensive so if it worked, I would keep it. However, it did not work -- it caused the Blue Screen of Death.

The merchant falsely advertised that it was OEM packaging, they never answered my question about their offer to replace it, when I asked if the replacement would have the OEM sealed packaging and so I opted to get a refund.

Reviews.title: Powerful card but overpriced
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States 🇺🇸 on October 21, 2018
Reviews.text:
When the Volta series GPU came out they tripled the price of the Titan. This put's it out of the rage for gamer's. It is still much cheaper than a Quadro and a Tesla card. This is thus intended for developer interested in training large deep neural nets (DNN's) on a budget. Found I could buy 2 for the price of one Tesla and figured that was probably a better deal.
Haven't gotten around to training any large neural nets yet, but I have tested it with with small ones the performance seems good. Also tested it with a game (Thalos Principle) on a 4K 35" monitor and and the performance is great.

Card is Hot. Runs at 85 degrees. I put on a custom water cooled copper block from AlfaCool. Not for the faint of heart. Lot of strange screws and nuts in strange dimensions, like a 4 mm double square nuts. Otherwise straight forward. That had a dramatic effect on the operating temperature and bought me some peace of mind. DNNs have to run at high loads for extended durations..

Reviews.title: HD5770s and 6770s never came with 4GB of VRAM! AVOID!!
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States 🇺🇸 on July 21, 2022
Reviews.text:
The vast majority of HD6770s did not come with a VGA port. The real ones also require a 6-pin power connector. Most cards that have an output layout like this are fake and, seeing reviews from people saying it won't run DX11, I'm inclined to believe this isn't even a 6770 as those did run DX11. The listed clock speed is about 200mhz lower than the original cards which, at best, points to these being faulty cards flashed with a different BIOS to operate at a lower clock speed. HD 5770s and 6770s (same card with 2 names) also NEVER came with 4GB of VRAM.

Again, this points to this being a card with a fake BIOS. I've tested another faked GPU claiming to be a GTX 960 4GB and the card even reported itself as such to the computer. In actuality it was a GT640 with 1GB of VRAM. When a game would try to utilize the reported 4GB of VRAM that didn't exist, it would cause the computer to crash.

Best case scenario here, you get a GPU that was originally released in 2009 (as the 5770, again, identical to the 6770...AMD just renamed the same card 2 years later) which has not received driver support since 2015, running at 76% of it's original speed (which may be how it gets away without a 6 pin power connector...but I doubt it) and have to spend some time dialing in settings to avoid games using more than 1GB of VRAM so the computer won't crash. In other words KEEP SHOPPING!

Reviews.title: Great budget card
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States 🇺🇸 on October 12, 2022
Reviews.text:
Old man Dad on a budget here. Purchased this to upgrade from onboard graphics when stadia was announced that they were cancelling.

Slapped it in, loaded up Elder Scrolls Online and can say I'm pleased with the card. I run it on the high setting no problem. It can handle ultra but the framerate drops below my comfort but it can run it.

For a budget card it works well for me. Would recommend.

(I'm running a 10th gen core i5 with only 16gb of ram...still the card performs better than expected)

Reviews.title: I NEEDED A CARD TO CRUISE AROUND THE INTERNET WITHOUT ISSUE AND THIS IS IT!
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States 🇺🇸 on March 8, 2022
Reviews.text:
I just needed a basic video card to cruise around the internet without being stifled by lame performance of a cheap video card. While this card is a tad expensive it is not priced at the ridiculously insane prices of the middle to high end gaming video cards in 2022. This GPU has done the job of letting me go anywhere on the internet without video lag.

I had a more expensive NVIDIA GPU in my system with otherwise state of the art hardware. The newest most power Ryzen 9 \ 5900 CPU, fast memory and a 750 watt power supply. The NVIDIA GPU ran like hot garbage on my Ubuntu system. Ubuntu has a nasty sepia color scheme that saturates the entire OS and everything in it. It is not only ugly but painful to look at due to my vision issues.

I did not know for sure at the time but, I hoped a new video card from someone other than NVIDIA might perform better. Turns out this AMD designed GPU got rid of the nasty sepia tint. This video card creates a simple un-tinted OS that is a pleasure to use. The card is not BIG and uses only the power supplied by the GPU slot.

The card has some energy saver garbage installed that turns the card off if you power down your monitor. I took a star off for the energy saver mess. There really are no other issues. This is a great card to use on a Linux\Ubuntu system that is not used for hard core gaming.

Reviews.text:
At my workplace I needed this half-height graphics card for a PC running a graphics intensive application that was practically unusable using the on-board graphics on the PC. Installing this card resolved the performance issues. I was pleased enough with that purchase that I bought one for my home computer to resolve some lag issues when playing 4K video on my old PC. This card resolved that issue, too. I don't know how this product benchmarks against the completion. I didn't do any testing like that. I simply had performance issues with applications that needed a graphics card performance boost. The price was right on this graphics card and I found that it worked fine to resolve those issues.

The only issue that I had was that the package came with no English instructions, no drivers and no software. I am an IT technician by trade, so I had little trouble finding the right drivers and software online. On one PC, Windows Update found the drivers, but I still had to download and install the correct version of the Radeon software. On the other PC I had to download both the drivers and software. So, this wasn't much of a problem for me, but it may be more than a novice PC users can deal with.

This product did what I needed and I've had no problems with it either at home or at work. It gets a 5 star rating from me even though I would have expected better instructions for installing the product and obtaining the correct drivers & software.

Reviews.title: Works Great. No Extra Power Needed.
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States 🇺🇸 on June 27, 2022
Reviews.text: I needed a low profile video card for a small form factor computer that didn't require it's own power source, and didn't cost a fortune. This one fit all 3 requirements. It was a simple install and the software was easy to find and download.

Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in Germany 🇩🇪 on August 29, 2022
Reviews.text:
Diese Grafikkarte ist absolout NICHT VR fähig ! Wer VR möchte MUSS mehr investieren !

Dennoch möchte ich diese Grafikkarte einmal für ihre erstaunliche und herausragende Leistung loben.
Hier hat MAXSUN alles richtig gemacht!

Ich habe einen Rechner mit ordentlich Leistung und natürlich auch mit einer entsprechenden Grafikkarte um damit die Valve Index VR-Brille zu betreiben. Ich bekam ein ausrangiertes Fujitsu Esprimo C710 mit USB3.0 und einem betagten aber ausreichenden Prozessor und suchte nun nach einer Low Profile Grafikkarte, die dabei auch noch schlank und bestmögliche Leistung bringen sollte.

Mein verrückter Plan:
Wenn an meinem Rechner was abraucht, sollte der kleine Esprimo das Ganze überbrücken.
Mit 32GB RAM und der MAXSUN Radeon RX 550 ist mir das sehr gut gelungen.
Wir reden hier natürlich von minimalistischen Grafikeinstellungen ABER BeatSaber, Phasmophobia (SinglePlayer), Pistol Whip und Blade & Sorcery sind durchaus spielbar und die Karte wird dabei nicht übermäßig heiß. Half Life - Alyx hingegen lagt sehr deutlich (wie es auch zu erwarten ist)

Dies ist keine Kaufempfehlung für VR, es soll aber verdeutlichen, was die kleine Karte auf dem Kasten hat.
Denn hier schlägt sie die vergleichbare GT 1030 um längen. Für Titel wie Diablo III und Co ifinde ich die RX 550 völlig in Ordnung und sie macht dort auch eine echt gute Figur.

Fazit: Es gibt natürlich deutlich stärkere Grafikkarten, egal ob AMD oder NVIDIA aber wer bei dem aktuellen Auf und Ab der Grafikkartenpreise eine günstige und verhältnismäßig starke Grafikkarte sucht, weil er sich gerade keine große leisten kann oder wie bei mir für einen kleineren Zweitrechner, sollte hier gut bedient sein.

Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in Germany 🇩🇪 on September 7, 2022
Reviews.text:
Hab wirklich lange und intensiv nach einer neuen, bezahlbaren und vom Preis nicht so abgehobenen Grafikkarte gesucht. Hier passt das Preis/Leistungsverhältnis für mich gerade noch so. Wir zocken wenig wenn dann Strategiespiele, Autorennen usw eine unserer Anforderungen war die Grafik entscheidend zu verbessern ohne Unmengen Geld zu investieren. Also neuer Monitor, Grafikkarte und ein zusätzlicher Speicherblock. Das Ergebnis kann sich mehr als sehen lassen!!!
Kein geruckel mehr und eine schön saubere Grafik, das beste die Grafikkarte wird bei uns nicht mal warm, läuft also alles sauber. Für 160€ kann man bei der Karte nichts verkehrt machen!

Reviews.text: Precio un pelin subido pero viendo lo que hay pues no esta mal se defiende bien con juegos como the witcher 3 asi que a mi me vale.

Preis Leistung ist gut.

Reviews.title: Works great
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States 🇺🇸 on August 25, 2022
Reviews.text: I use this graphics card for X-Plane on an older Intel 4790 that only supports DDR-3 memory. The program demands a lot of video resources, which the GD-1030 supplies. I cannot run at the highest frame rates, but it runs quite well. I am very satisfied with this graphics card.

Reviews.title: A solution to a problem.
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States 🇺🇸 on April 6, 2022
Reviews.text:
A family member had their monitor burn out and a 4K monitor was bought. Sadly, the built-in video card in the older computer was not strong enough to support the max resolution.

This video card did exactly that. And it is fine for a computer that is used for surfing, basic desktop work, etc. But once you want to watch a full-screen 4K video it struggles. Badly.
To be fair here, the 10-series were not built for 4K. But it needs to be said: it is one thing to do static work on 4K resolutions; once you go to a high-quality media display this is not the card you are looking for.

So this card does what it needs to do - and it will perform fine for most things in resolutions under 4k. It is affordable and available. But don't buy this one for high-quality gaming or intensive video or animation work.

Reviews.title: Probably was a return
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States 🇺🇸 on January 2, 2022

No disk, manual, or anything for that matter other than the card. Obviously a return. Forewarned is forearmed and I had already gone to the Maxsun website and downloaded the latest drivers. I installed the card and, in fairness, works as advertised. The vendor just needs to ensure that the documentation is in every box. I also haven't registered it (no disk asking me to) but will do that on the website. Arrived on time.

Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States 🇺🇸 on October 8, 2021

Overall it's slim will definitely fit in a modular case and does the trick of you are looking to do anything that's graphic hungry. Minus of course Fortnite at 60fps consistent. The value is peek. The extra 2gb of room helps to. Hope this is your final review to read before pulling the trigger. I did , great product in an oversaturated market currently

If you're looking for a good GPU for 3D dense programs such as Second Life, this one is more then capable with the sacrifice of FPS (25-30 at High, 10-15 at Ultra graphics settings).

data.label: Fourth Level MFG Atlas Graphics Card Brace, Anti Sag, Deepcool GPU Support, Video Card Holder, for Custom Desktop PC Gaming, Acrylic GPU Stand Case Mod, Bitcoin, Mining

Reviews.title: Love it!
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States 🇺🇸 on July 25, 2017
Reviews.text:
Love the aesthetic value it adds to my build. [Except the 4-5 port USB 3.0 PCI-Express card I have in it (it's the bright color of red I would live to see if a 69 Camaro SS or Fender Stratocaster)]. So it's slated to be painted or Colored on top...after I look into whether that could fry it or not. ANYWAY... Not only does it look very nice/awesome. It can definitely ease much of the strain that is placed more and more on your PCI-E x16 or x8 slots these days (My card is an EVGA Geforce GTX 1080 SSC ITX. The thing weighs three pounds. Don't open another tab to fact check that. It says so in the specs, it's an impressive beast of a card.

The outer side of this brace has a nice matte-type texture, but TAKE NOTE: If your graphics card is 2.5 slots thick, the instructions state that you will need to use it with the brace flipped over, [lonely screw point down. If this is the case for you, the side that will be facing out is smooth with a glassy shine. (nothing a little, light circular scraping with a nail file won't fix I imagine, but just a heads up)]. The manufacturer name is also not present on the inner side, which us unfortunate imho, because the name seams to suit such an accessory in such an intended location very nicely and even contribute to the cool factor :).

A couple other things you should know. 1. If you're like me and you have a bunch of punched out expansion slots on your case. Make sure the ones that are not occupied are closed with some nice slot covers/blanks. It says so in the instructions for good reason tightening all the screws on an uneven surface can make things pretty off center, including the stress placed on the screw holes of an unoccupied slot.

2. You only get four bumper pads. The adhesive is amazing, very strong, but take your sweetest of time planning exactly where they are going to go. I mean it. Put the brace on screws and all and see if you need to do a little bending of the metal between the slot opening to make sure the screws will be perpendicular to the back plate ahead of time, because a couple degrees looks pretty big by the time your eyes reach the other end of the brace, and the adhesive isn't meant to have the bumper pads be repeatedly removed and reapplied. Because you didn't scope things out ahead of time (Learn from my mistake :) ).

Another plus is the brace can help obscure the view of less flattering cards. just don't put them on the middle hole if they will impede air flow to the GPU and you love your graphics card.

Just take your time with a ruler and make a couple little pit marks with a knife point or something, and mark the places you want the bumpers after having seen where they will fit with the brace in the ideal position (use the screws when checking this! don't "eye ball" this.

In short. I love it. I would have given 4.5 stars, but sadly this is not yet an option.

The only thing they could do better would be to include more bumper pads for if /WHEN you miss a detail.

If you are like me and sometimes read more reviews after buying, don't panic, 4th Level Manufacturing will send you more bumpers at no charge if you need more!

I wonder if they come in different colors??? :)

Reviews.title: Good for smaller cards.
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States 🇺🇸 on September 3, 2022
Reviews.text: It looks nice but it is not built to hold up cards that REALLY have weight to them. Up against my Red Devil 6900XT the Atlas brace snapped pitifully.

Reviews.title: Bought for my MSI 1070 Gaming card; ended up being redundant
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States 🇺🇸 on August 24, 2016
Reviews.text:
I bought this product to help hold up my MSI GeForce GTX 1070 Gaming 8G card. Turns out that the backplate of the card keeps it pretty rigid, but it's a good peace of mind to know that the bulky thing is being held up at the end of it. I also picked this brace over the countless other designs out there because it looks cool as a sort of truss design (it is a kind of plastic material, but is sound enough to do the job).

My one issue was this with my case and this card, I couldn't put the brace between the case and the card. There was about 1/4 or so of an inch too much material to put it in as shown in the product images. I easily remedied this by just flipping the brace upside down, and using two of the sticker bumps that are provided. It needs three screw holes from the video card panels on the back panel of your case, so instead of doing the bottom GPU screw and the two below it, I just used the three screws below the GPU. Easy solution. Just know that the "front" of the brace is a sort of matte black, whereas the "back" is a little more plastic-like. The front is also where the small Atlas logo is printed.

The manufacturer sent an email when I purchased the product saying that they'd be very willing to send extra copies of anything provided (the sticker bumps and screws) for free. I liked that, but the materials originally provided have so far sufficed.

Overall pretty happy, even if it's such a simple object that ended up being redundant anyway.

Edit:
Bought another one for my brother's card. His showed up as a sort of painted piece of hardwood, rather than plastic. His bumps were also different than mine. I had clear bumps and two were flat topped, the other two rounded. All four of my brother's were these semi-skini cylindrical black rubber bumps. Not really a complaint, but just know that there seems to be more than one kind that you can get here.

Reviews.title: This worked pretty well for my MSI 1070 Gaming X and the ...
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States 🇺🇸 on May 12, 2018
Reviews.text:
This worked pretty well for my MSI 1070 Gaming X and the NZXT H440 case. The card is level now and the fans seems to be spinning fine. Couple of points:

- The bump dots' adhesive doesn't stay on the bump dots very well when taking them off the sheet, so you have to be pretty careful or the adhesive will be ruined. That being said, there were five or six bump dots included.

- It is made out of plastic. Not a big deal as it is pretty thick and sturdy and now looking through other reviews, I see that mentioned. I would have liked it mentioned in the product description. A bit of a high price for plastic.

- It would have been better if, as others have mentioned, it came with some offsets. While the bump dots to make it so it doesn't come in contact with the fans, having out further on the edge of the card would keep it entirely away from the fans and supported better. Just another thing that I need to buy and for the overall price of the product should have been included.

Overall, it worked well and I would recommend it. If you do have the H440 and two cards, this will not work for any card unless it is in the top slot. There isn't enough room for with the second slot or at least it would be a very close fit, if at all.

Reviews.title: Works wonderfully, and looks great!
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States 🇺🇸 on December 19, 2017
Reviews.text:
I cannot speak for the others who have given this a bad review, perhaps it's user error, perhaps I got lucky. I will however say that this thing has done a great job so far of supporting my GPU. There is a specific order of steps I've found to achieve optimal support which I will explain briefly.

I found that by placing the rubber risers along the length of the brace, and loosely installing the brace onto the pcie slots, you can apply upwards pressure onto the card and brace without causing flex. Once you've achieved a flat plane, and you're satisfied with it's position, you need to tighten the top and bottom screws as tight as you can, then the middle. They have to be very tight, and you will need the washers or else I would imagine you will crack the brace as it seems to made of a hard plastic. I followed these steps, and took my time to perfect it and I've achieved a perfectly straight plane, while looking great. Keep in mind I have a huge and heavy FTW GTX1080 Hybrid watercooled card, and this things still manages to support her.

Install it however you find suitable, just take your time and remember it's plastic. Worth every penny in my opinion.

Reviews.title: Mehhh.....It does the job I guess....
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States 🇺🇸 on September 30, 2016
Reviews.text: Ok, well it arrived. That being said, it's the most difficult thing to install in my new rebuilt PC. New MB, new case, new cooler, and2 new ssds. It does what it says. It makes the GPU level, finally! My last case did this without any work put into it. At first impressions this does get some stars. Good, well built piece of plastic that is reinforced, and does hold up the GPU. Just not aesthetically pleasing. Sags worse than the video card after install. Did come with black screws and washers, which was a plus in my book. Installing into a Fractile Design Define R5 White Edition with window. Everything matched great. Had some trial and error with my MSi GTX 970 100ME. Though the final install did work without messing with the fans. The Rubber stand-offs were hard to place, PCI slot covers, which I was not willing to part with, were hard to place when in the upright position. Ended up having to defy the instructions and place the case on the side just to start to screw down the plate. After install looks awkward in the case itself. Will be adjusting and will hopefully update when I do. Sorry, I work 7 days a week and have no time to do this awesome stuff anymore like I used to.

Reviews.title: My MSI GTX 1070 Gaming X is level now!
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States 🇺🇸 on June 4, 2017
Reviews.text: Glad that I found the Atlas Graphics Card Brace. Even though my MSI board has steel reinforced PCI slots, I was uncomfortable with how much my MSI GTX 1070 Gaming X sagged from the weight of the card. I did look at other adapters and options, and the Atlas Brace was the most attractive to me. Before I ordered I was concerned about needing spacers or other hardware like some have said, but no additional hardware was needed for my case - NZXT S340 Elite. It came in a simple box with instructions, 4 adhesive bumpers, 3 screws, and 3 washers. At first I thought it was pretty silly to ad the detailed instructions, but it ended up being very helpful. The installation of the Atlas brace went easy after I figured out where I going to place the rubber bumpers. I did double up the bumpers in the center of the graphics card while placing the others on the plastic area just outside the fan on the right. The fans spin without interruption and now my MSI 1070 is level without all that weight on the slot of my motherboard. The plate on the back of the NZXT case that helps hold the PCI slot covers in place now doesn't close all the way the way it did before. It leaves a space the width of the Atlas Brace, but it's fine. The plate still goes on and covers most of what it should. I do like the matte look of the brace. It doesn't take away or distract from my graphics card. You notice it, but you don't see it first. Overall great product.

Reviews.title: Amazing product.
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States 🇺🇸 on October 18, 2016
Reviews.text:
Worked perfectly.
I currently have a Windforce Xtreme gaming 970, which is a very big card, and I have had it for 6 months. After a while it started to sag slightly and then caused one of my fans to slightly tick at high RPMs. I noticed if I held up the card slightly it would stop ticking. I set out to find a GPU brace that I knew I could trust and also looked great in my build.
This brace is perfect.

I want it to be known that this brace once purchased was followed up by a HAND TYPED email directly thanking me for buying the product and giving me contacts of which I could use if I had any problems or needed extra pieces for my card, free of charge.

The only thing (and I mean that really) ONLY THING that I could even say slightly caused a problem wasn't even caused by the company, it was caused by me. So on the edge of the L-shaped part of the bracket (the part where you screw the brace into the PCI bracket spots) there are 3 little humps that are there I believe purely for design. One of them was hitting a rivet used to hold a piece of my case together, so I had to use a flap disc on an angle grinder and flatten it out to get it to fit in my case. (I included a picture of this so its easier to understand)

Everything about this brace I love.
It works perfectly and I would highly recommend it to anyone needing a similar product.

Reviews.title: Best GPU brace at any price!
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States 🇺🇸 on February 8, 2017
Reviews.text:
I ordered two of these braces for my two computers running GTX 1070s and I am 100% satisfied with the purchase. They arrived exactly as described and have taken all of the sag out of each graphics card, one of which had a very noticeable sag! An added bonus is that they look awesome - both of my computers have side windows so the look was a concern.

Some of the reviewers have been negative regarding the strength of these braces allegedly causing them to crack or fracture during installation. After installing these braces into two computers, I can attest to the fact that they are neither brittle nor weak. My only guess is that those reviewers must have either mishandled the product or used a high torque drill to install them. A simple phillips head screwdriver and four minutes of your time is all it takes. I do recommend installing with the computer resting on it's side in order to facilitate the proper placement of the rubber stays to clear the GPU fans.

My last thought is regarding the price. A lot of reviewers have complained that you are only getting a piece of plastic with some screws and washers for almost $20. In my opinion, the functionality of this item makes it worth every penny. They do exactly what you need to protect your GPU card, which cost hundreds of dollars in my case, and they do it while looking great in the process. To my way of thinking - that's priceless!

Reviews.title: Great quality but doesn't fit the RTX 2070 Ultra
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States 🇺🇸 on March 14, 2019
Reviews.text:
The quality is awesome and the packaging and parts are really put together with care. American made. I like that! Super light weight and unobtrusive which is exactly what I wanted for my build. The only problem I have is it doesnt work for my GPU, unfortunately. I would have to modify it to use it. I have an EVGA RTX 2070 XC Ultra which means an abnormally large cooling radiator (really thick). The extra thickness places the screw holes for the case directly underneath the dividers between the factory cut screw slots in the brace. I knocked off 1 star because its not a universal brace but, the EVGA 2070 Ultra is a relitively new card.
I would have done a half star if it would let me because it really is a well crafted piece. Overall, super happy with it and will probably hold onto it for another build someday. Until then, I'll have to find an alternative because this card is surprisingly heavy.

Reviews.title: It works and is great value if upgrading from a 700-900 series.
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States 🇺🇸 on August 2, 2019
Reviews.text: I have replaced my 760 192-bit NVIDIA in my Acer Predator. This is still a great value for price. I know others will tell you to hop onto the 2060 and use a Molex 6 pin to 8 pin connector for ray-tracing and various other things or a 1660 TI(which is not much of an upgrade). But i would tell you to get this instead as it is 150$ cheaper and if you are looking into a solid budget to not spend a lot this would be it as it does work with VR without much issues. Also looking at other reviews i had no issues upgrading my graphics card and no issues at all with the drivers. Nvidia Geforce program recognized my Asus and immediately installed the proper drivers needed once i took my old Graphics card out, put in the new one and booted up my PC. The only small star knockoff was the slight measurement that ASUS had for the GPU it ended up being correct on the vertical and the length, but not the horizontal it was only a tiny bit fatter on the sides. Still fit my PC but it was almost a slight close call nothing huge though. Also i would recommend this to anyone upgrading from the 900-700 series but would like something more on the budget side for a few years before going for higher end or those looking to go for something that will last a long time and be energy efficient. This would do really well.

Reviews.title: Video editing on a Dell Inspiron 3670
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States 🇺🇸 on May 24, 2019
Reviews.text:
Dell Inspiron 3670 i7 8th Generation are sprightly mid-range business machines that offer very good bang for buck as far as performance but, and it is a big BUT Dell really, really don't want you to extend their use outside of business. My need was for a machine that would happily work Davinci Resolve movie editing. This GPU works just fine for that, but to do so I had to add an external power supply and ditch the on-board PSU for the Dell. There are NO spare power taps on the 3670 - no supplementary power for cards or additional drives. The ATX mobo connection is also special.

I used a Corsair CX Series Modular Power Supply PLUS a 24-pin to 8-Pin adapter to power the mobo, that also gave the power to the GPU, and power to a second drive so I could switch to an SSD plus the original HDD as a data store.

The new PSU sits on top of the case - not to everyone's taste - but it all works very happily and is almost silent.

However, if you purchase this card through Amazon, you will not get any of the free games that are currently being offered through other resellers, such as Anthem, Battlefield V or Metro Exodus.
---
Update : The promotional period runs until 4/25/19 and Amazon is now offering redemption codes. If you haven't received a code from Amazon via email, contact support and they will sort you out ASAP. Amazon Rocks.

The downside is Nvidia will require you to download and install the Geforce Experience software and create a Nvidia account before you're able to redeem it. You will then get ANOTHER code. Then you will likely have to create yet another account and download even more software from the game creator. This is a PITA, but I upgraded my rating to 5 stars since the card itself is performing great.

Reviews.title: Perfect High/Ultra 1080p 60fps Gaming
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States 🇺🇸 on January 4, 2018
Reviews.text: This graphics card is perfect for modern titles at high-ultra settings on modern games, epecially when it's paired with a decent mid range processor, like the ryzen 5 1600 or i5-8400. It's pretty small for a Graphics card, so it could probably fit in a smaller micro atx case if needed. Most modern games, including GTA V, The Witcher III, Dishonored 2, Destiny 2, PUBG, and many other AAA games utilize about 3-4 Gb of VRAM, so this graphics card is perfect for handling modern titles at 60fps on high-ultra settings. If you are looking for future proofing, you may want to grab the 6gb version of the card, however, if you plan on upgrading in a year or two, this will get you through a few seasons before going for an Nvidia 20-series GPU.

If you want to use it for high 1440 or 4k games FPS than I say get the 2070 or 2080 card.

Using Passmark Benchmark I get a 3d score of 16000+ with a 17-4790k CPU. The 1060 3mb card I had before only got a score of 10000 or so.

data.description: Sapphire Radeon Pulse RX 550 2GB GDDR5 64-bit HDMI / DVI-D / DP OC (UEFI) PCI-E Graphics Card.

Reviews.title: Edit: The product turned out to NOT be what was advertised
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States 🇺🇸 on July 12, 2020
Reviews.text:
I'll keep the text of my previous review to show how duped I was. I had purchased this before I saw the answer to my question about why this card was cheaper than expected. And it's because it's a Radeon 550, NOT a Radeon RX 500 or a Radeon 550X and certainly not a Radeon RX 550X.

I think that AMD bears some of the blame in how they are naming the variants. The RX and the non-RX differ in the memory bus width. The RX being 128 and the non-RX being 64. But the seller is definitely misleading by stating that this is an RX 550, though they do call out 64 bit in the name.

I think that the price I paid was commensurate to it being a Radeon 550, and it being a one slot, lower power product is actually a plus. It has enough power for what I do and it supports HDR10. So the only issue I have is with the product name being misleading.

------------------------------------------
Initial review below:
When I first ordered this, I was very suspicious of the price. It was $20-$30 lower than all the other 2GB RX 550 cards. And the delivery date was going to be weeks after the order. I ended up getting it much sooner than expected, and it looks future deliveries will be much quicker. So maybe an inventory issue.

Once I received the card, I looked for any signs that this was fake or some other even cheaper card made to look like the RX 550. The card seems real. It's installed and working without a problem. The only quibble is the instructions. It's generic. It talks about having to connect the card to a power supply. That's not true. Just plug it and it'll get sufficient power from the bus.

Don't expect to play the latest games at 4K with this card. It's a budget graphics card, enough to play some older games without any issues (Skyrim, for example). For this price, it's excellent.

Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States 🇺🇸 on October 24, 2020
Reviews.text:
This card is one of the better budget options available to customers and offers more than an equally priced nvidia card. It was purchased to provide dual monitor support to a client and it works perfectly. Don't think it will do very well for graphics intensive games but the casual gamer might be ok here.

Things to note:
the shroud of this card pushes it into the next slot so i would class it as being 1.5 slots tall. Be mindful of this if you plan to use the expansion just below the PCIex16 slot
The fan stays off when the GPU isn't stressed and only comes on when it heats up
The package is very minimal and only contains the Card and a Drivers Disc. There are no adapters packaged with this card.
